149844828.review: I like the gameplay and the ice cave area is fun, but it is very short and I could've cared less about the story. This game is from 2014, so maybe I can excuse how bad the characters look and how empty the areas are. You can barely interact with anything, even though you are expected to explore the village areas. The best part is the movement. Once you get the rocket boots, it is super fun flying around from platform to platform and barely recovering when you mess up. I wish you could use the rocket boots throughout more of the game. 149795647.review:
Kind of a B-grade Mirror's Edge.. except it actually gives me a bit of a headache, whereas Mirror's Edge does not.  Turning off the motion blur, and reducing the FoV to 75' helps a bunch.

SUPER short.  I didn't finish, but I watched my kids finish it from around the point I stopped, and... I was probably 30% in, after only like 1 hour.  Not really worth it for the price, IMO -- the platforming (and secrets discovery along the way) is all there is, and it's all failure unless you are retracing or going on the anointed path -- which is sometimes pretty hard to spot.  I would guess that about 1/3rd of this game is guessing where the path is, and another 1/3rd is respawning and trying to same trick, which you can figure out, but not manage the timing of without some luck, over and over again.

The controls are not very forgiving... ironically extending the short game (in a bad way).  Not sure if it's intentional, but it doesn't feel good -- you feel like you're fighting with them a bit, not immersed.

It looks like a high res X360/PS3 port to 4K 60 Hz.. like they upscaled the textures, but it doesn't look pro.  The models are low res.  The animations are.. certainly not motion-captured, and not overly good.  The art execution is meh, but the style is good.  It is charming, and the story is fun.

If you're tolerant of very typical indie-grade art and gameplay design, love a good story (the best part of this title, along with the art style choices), and can get this on sale, you might want to take a look.

148993582.review:
Han pasado muchos años desde la primera vez que me pase este juego, y aun así, siempre vuelvo a el para darle una pasadita rápida y perderme un ratete en el mundo que ofrece A Story About My Uncle. En fin, la historia sobre mi tío, es un juego muy sencillo en la practica y que no tiene mucho misterio, es básicamente un plataformero rápido, con mucha mucha mecánica de grappling y mucho movimiento aéreo, lo cual le da un punto y un ritmo diferente al juego. Muy cortito, se disfruta en un par de horas, quizás un poquito mas dependiendo del ritmo de cada uno. La historia tampoco es que sea, lo mas profundo que vais a encontrar por ahí, pero al que le pegue en casa cerquita, y el que pueda entenderla un poco mas allá, y entienda los mensajes subliminales que va dejando, la va a disfrutar, es básicamente un cuento al fin y al cabo.

Gráficamente es bonito, y con muy poco, consigue bastante. No es que sea ningún portento, pero vaya, lo que hace, lo hace bien! Lo mismo con la música, tiene sus temas destacables, que saben cuando sonar y romper un poco el silencio general que tiene el juego.

Es un juego que pertenece a la epoca en la que los indies, eran jodidamente indies de cojones, y se nota, y en parte eso es lo que lo hace tan magico a su manera.

No es ninguna obra maestra, pero es un muy muy buen juego, y que realmente poco hace mal. Me encantaria una secuela que añada mas cosillas al movimiento y por supuesto con un nuevo lavado de cara, pero bueno, es mas complicado.

Le doy un 8/10 para el juego que es. Muy recomendado, sobre todo si estáis con fiebre de mirrors edge, o de simplemente desconectar y pasar un buen rato moviéndote y disfrutando de lo que el juego tiene para ofrecer!

[h1] Should've been a 20-min Unreal demo [/h1]
[b]Progress at the time of this review[/b]: 0/15 Achievements, finished the main campaign
[b]Rating[/b]: 4/10
[b]Verdict[/b]: The game looks good but doesn't have any substance underneath, gameplay- or story-wise.

[b]Positives[/b]:
[list]
    [*]The graphics look good. But even then, the art style doesn't really have any distinct, memorable flavor or character, and in the end the technically applaudable graphics served nothing more than the disposable wrappings of the nothingburger that is this game.
    [*]The instant respawn feature is essential and it made the game substantially less frustrating.
[/list]
[b]Negatives[/b]:
[list]
    [*]The game poses as a parkour game, but I never once experienced the flow of movement (think [i]Mirror's Edge[/i]) I would expect. The grappling device and the boots are simply not fun to use.
    [*]The level design is uninteresting at best and tedious at worst, and the clunky movement made this flaw stand out even more. I was so often disoriented and uncertain which direction I was supposed to go in next because there weren't enough visual cues for me to latch onto.
    [*]Everything about the writing is just so, so boring. Too little is explained throughout the course of the game, and consequently the bland ending failed to deliver any emotional impact even though it's trying so hard to.
[/list]

146907496.review:
[h1] "Swinging Through Memories: A Story About My Uncle" [/h1]

"A Story About My Uncle" might have a peculiar title, but it's fitting because, as you dive into this adventure, you're essentially reminiscing about your character's quest to find his uncle, Fred. It all begins with a heartfelt conversation with your daughter, weaving together past and present.

You start by exploring Fred's home in search of him, but your quest takes an unexpected twist when you stumble upon his observatory and a custom-fitted power suit designed just for you. This suit transforms your journey into a mesmerizing, gravity-defying experience.

This game stands as a rare breed—a first-person platformer. We've seen glimpses of this genre, notably in "Mirror's Edge," but here, it focuses on precision platforming that quickly puts your skills to the test.

You're armed with a versatile toolkit from the get-go, including basic jumps, power jumps, and a trusty grappling hook. The challenges come at you swiftly, introducing you to these mechanics through a thrilling obstacle course that seamlessly integrates with the narrative.

You'll encounter Maddie, a young frog-like creature living in a village who knew your uncle. They join you in your search, offering their assistance. The plot thickens as you uncover mysteries and the village's peculiar frog-like residents. Beneath the seemingly innocent surface, fear and uncertainty linger.

The game's mechanics are relatively straightforward, but they demand precision. You must master the art of momentum, angle, and timing for jumps and grappling hook use. Aiming for that perfect swing is both thrilling and challenging. The controls, whether on a gamepad or keyboard and mouse, are intuitive and responsive.

What sets this game apart is its narrative. It boasts substantial dialogue and a compelling story, despite occasional language and voice acting hiccups. You genuinely care about the characters and their fates. The early sections of the game, with their slower pacing, draw you into the world, allowing you to see your uncle not just as a plot device but as a person.

Trial and error are the name of the game here, but constant checkpoints and instant respawns ease the frustration of failing challenging platforming segments.

Visually, the game shines, with vibrant lighting effects and breathtaking scenes. Character models, however, seem dated in comparison.

The sound design masterfully crafts an atmospheric and unsettling ambiance, immersing you in a world where fear lurks in the shadows, despite the absence of traditional enemies.

In conclusion, "A Story About My Uncle" transcends its individual components to create an exceptional experience. Its compelling story, impressive visuals, and demanding yet fair platforming challenges make it a must-play for those who appreciate games that both challenge the mind and the reflexes.

146491846.review:
A world and art style that is so rich, beautiful, and interesting that I forgot I only bought this game because leafy was always playing it. One of the most modern platformers I have ever seen, especially first person ones. Fun and intuitive grapple hook controls, jump-started with a decent learning curve that continues throughout the game with long and deep depths below you that give the player a real sense of tactics and caution, keeping you having to use your grapples sparingly and intelligently. And yet the game is still relaxing and tension free when you get to take in the colorful and toon-like art style while overcoming the simple obstacles of the gameplay. Jungles, mountains, caves, caverns, cute villages made of sticks and blankets inhabited by little fascinating creatures, all designed with a childhood innocence perfection. 

It's a feeling of thrill that helps keep you going on this beautiful and wondrous adventure, even sometimes emotional. The perfect game for lazy days when you don't want to think, you just want to appreciate just want to explore a new world by souring through it at top speed but at the same time, want to challenge yourself in a way that rewards you for doing something so simple and inventive. The more at peace you are, the better you play.

Buy it

145094267.review:
A whimsical but dark bedtime story, presented as a challenging (and sometimes infuriating) puzzle platformer. 

I felt like the world was underutilized, but I suppose you could argue that the world was not meant to be the focus, given the full context of the story. Of course, the story itself is somewhat ambiguous in its ending and meaning. 

Ultimately, I feel like I can't recommend the game. It does some interesting things, some unique things in the area of story and art direction, but you can't just do something unique, you have to make it interesting and do it well. Ultimately, my favorite parts of the story (early on) were never really developed, and at a certain point I didn't see any more of the story content I actually enjoyed, just platforming segments until an ambiguous ending. 

Though, if you feel interesting after looking through the store page and watching the trailer, you very well will probably enjoy the game.

144922641.review:
I liked it at first.
Grapples and super jumps, my kind of gameplay.
There's nothing else, yet I would be fine with that.
However, past the 1st village, the level design is awful and keeps getting worse.

Firstly, it's beyond dark.
It's pitch black.
With gamma set very high, I still can't distinguish between the floor, the walls, and the void.
Perfect for constant falls while walking blind.
Great for wrongly estimating distances as well.

Then there's no sense of orientation, no compass, very few recognisable landmarks.
I can never tell if I'm walking forward or backtracking. It becomes truly painful inside the black cave.

Issues continue piling up with the severe lack of checkpoints, and their horrible placement.
Obviously, the exploration is utterly ruined; if there is any to begin with.

Not to forget the giant eye that forces you to wait between jumps; a bonus dose of anti-fun.
Passing it brings no satisfaction, only a sigh of relief.
Unwarranted relief, because the following level isn't enjoyable either.

What's meant to be entertaining and relaxing turns out to be extremely taxing on wrists and thumbs. And joyless.

143301676.review:
"A Story About My Uncle" is an indie adventure game that offers a unique experience as a 3D platformer interwoven with a simple narrative. While the game boasts creative mechanics and a captivating atmosphere, it is not without its drawbacks. 

The jumping mechanic, which allows players to swing from point to point with a grappling hook, is the game's shining feature. It offers a sense of freedom and fluidity as you navigate this mysterious world. The sensation of soaring through the air is captivating, and zipping from platform to platform is very fun... when it works.

Sadly, the inconsistency in the jumping mechanics becomes apparent as you progress through the game. The length from which you can grapple to objects seems to change from puzzle to puzzle, which can be frustrating and disrupt the otherwise fun experience. The game's difficulty curve is uneven, often featuring sudden and unexpected spikes in challenges, especially in the last two stages. Some sections require very specific timing and execution, leading to frustrating trial-and-error gameplay.

This game is short, like two hours tops. I've got it heavily discounted for like two euros, so I can't really complain much about its shortcomings, but if I were to buy it at full price, I'd be pissed, to say the least.

Recommended, but at a discount.

5/10

Recommended only if you manage to get it for free. The game is too shortshort and with okay-ish quality to justify buying it. 142484467.review:
It's alright but short romp, though it doesn't really vary up or explore mechanics as much as it should. The background environments are big and expansive but you're largely traversing linear paths where you need to go and even grapple onto is always marked for you. I really wish there was more environmental variety as well, since most of the time you're in caves of some sort.

The story and characters are very forgettable. Events and beats just kinda happen and are skimmed over both by the game and the narrating protagonist. You're meant to care about characters who you know for only about 30 minutes. There's no tension or really anything to make you care about anyone, aside from the characterization the protagonist gives to his uncle by remarking on his personality and history.

I wouldn't get this full-price, but on sale or as part of a bundle it's more reasonable.

140546564.review:
A Story About My Uncle is a charming and enchanting adventure game that takes players on a journey through magical landscapes and heartwarming storytelling. With its unique gameplay mechanics, breathtaking environments, and heartfelt narrative, this indie gem offers an experience that is both captivating and emotionally resonant.

One of the standout features of A Story About My Uncle is its innovative movement system. As the player, you don the role of a young boy equipped with a grappling device, allowing you to traverse vast landscapes with fluidity and grace. The sense of freedom and exhilaration that comes from soaring through the air, swinging from platform to platform, is unparalleled. The game's intuitive controls and smooth animations make every leap and swing a joy to execute, creating a profound sense of exploration and discovery.

The game's world-building is truly a sight to behold. From vibrant, otherworldly caverns to floating cities and breathtaking vistas, each environment is meticulously crafted with attention to detail and artistic finesse. The imaginative level design invites you to immerse yourself in a world filled with mystery and wonder. The stunning visuals, accompanied by a beautiful soundtrack, work in harmony to create a truly immersive and enchanting experience.

Beyond its captivating gameplay and stunning visuals, A Story About My Uncle delivers a heartfelt narrative that touches the soul. The story unfolds through narration and dialogue, revealing the touching relationship between the protagonist and his uncle. It explores themes of family, love, and the power of determination. The emotional depth of the storytelling is enhanced by the well-written characters and their interactions, evoking a range of feelings as you progress through the game.

Additionally, A Story About My Uncle strikes a perfect balance between exploration and puzzle-solving. The game presents a series of challenging platforming sequences and puzzles that require both skill and critical thinking. Each new area introduces unique obstacles and mechanics, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging throughout the journey. The satisfaction of overcoming these challenges and uncovering the secrets of the world is immensely rewarding.

In conclusion, A Story About My Uncle is a hidden gem in the realm of indie games. Its innovative movement system, breathtaking environments, and heartfelt storytelling combine to create an unforgettable experience. The game's ability to evoke a sense of wonder and curiosity is a testament to its remarkable craftsmanship. If you're seeking a captivating adventure that will touch your heart and leave you in awe, A Story About My Uncle is an absolute must-play that will transport you to a world of magic and discovery.

139710482.review:
Juego sin mayores pretensiones que cumple su cometido. Buenas gráficas en cuanto a los niveles, salvo algún que otro detalle; en cuanto a los personajes no, pero recordemos que no estamos en presencia de un producto de los "Gigantes" del mercado.
La historia se centra en que la falta de noticias de nuestro tío nos motiva a seguirlo hasta su laboratorio, en el cual y luego de tocar una palanca, nos trasladará a otro mundo donde intentaremos seguirle la pista hasta dar con él.
En cuanto a la jugabilidad es bastante simple: solo debes saltar de una plataforma haciendo clicks con el mouse a la otra haciendo gala de una gravedad muy distinta a la Tierra. Si has jugado al Crysis, te recordará cuando seleccionabas "Máximo Poder" y te proponías a saltar para esquivar algún que otro obstáculo de la isla.
Entiendo que la idea ya ha sido utilizada pero aquí es el centro de esta entrega. Hay reminiscencias con películas como "Viaje al Centro de la Tierra" y demás.
Teniendo en cuenta que proviene de una empresa independiente, a la originalidad de sus escenarios y sumado a que no requiere mucho ordenador para "tirarlo", es un juego para recomendar

138243889.review:
If you look up the development of this game it's an indie made by a group of students in just 3 months, with little prior experience. It makes sense this isn't the longer or most in-depth experience ever, but the passion and creativity is there. 

This game will be fun for any casual gamer who enjoys first person platforming. The grapple is a fun mechanic and none of the platforming is overly difficult, and as long as you don't rely solely on markers you won't have any issues when the challenge increases later in the game.

My only issue with the game really is that it's SHORT for the price tag. $15 is fine for any indie, but I easily finished this game in under 2 hours. Not to discredit the developers, but I feel like this game should have a $5 price tag just because it doesn't have the length to justify $15.

137444451.review:
Too few checkpoints. I don't feel like walking 30 seconds to the start of a hard part every time I fail in the hard part. I demand immediate respawn in immediate proximity of the challenge. 

Also don't take away or limit the players abilities to make things harder but rather invent new game mechanics to mix it up. 

The environment (sound and visual) I applaud. The story not so much. It's very minimal but partly good. The problem is that every other voice actor is bad or in case of the protagonist passable. 

I liked what the game tried to make but the final product did not please me. To be honest maybe I wouldn't even write a negative review if this wasn't so well received here. I just wanted to share my negatives. 

In the end I applaud anyone who dears to make games that don't fit the basic box.

137075601.review:
La historia es conmovedora y emotiva, con personajes bien desarrollados y una narración envolvente. La jugabilidad es también muy interesante, con un sistema de movimiento acrobático que te permite explorar y saltar por un mundo mágico lleno de colores vibrantes y criaturas extrañas.

La banda sonora es impresionante y se adapta perfectamente a cada momento del juego, añadiendo una capa adicional de emoción y suspenso a medida que avanzas en la trama. Además, el juego es muy bien optimizado, con gráficos impresionantes que no comprometen el rendimiento.

En general, "A Story About My Uncle" es un juego que recomiendo altamente a cualquier persona que esté buscando una experiencia de juego única y emocionante. La combinación de una gran narrativa, jugabilidad acrobática y gráficos impresionantes hace que este juego sea realmente especial y vale la pena jugarlo.

136372873.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

JUGADO COMPLETAMENTE EN STEAM DECK.

A Story About my Uncle es un juego particular sin duda, con una curva de aprendizaje correcta que va desde etapas muy sencillas a cada vez más complejas donde en el final se pone a prueba lo que has ido aprendiendo por el camino. 

En el Juego hay varias mecánicas muy repetitivas:

-Correr

134853025.review:
A Story About My Uncle, (despite having a sussy name), is a heartfelt experience that tells a short yet captivating story about family, grief and preserving legacy.

 - Story beats are awarded to the player via exploration, as the laid back platforming takes the centre stage. A Story About My Uncle sends you flying through the skies at breakneck paces but it never feels intense or overbearingly difficult. The whole game gives an extremely lucid vibe, and its accompanied with stunning visuals and an appropriately ambient soundtrack. The controls are admittedly a little slippery, but after a bit of trial and error, I got the hang of knowing what to click and where to go.

 - This game is pretty short, clocking in at around 3 hours if you take your time. I've gone through to try and get all the achievements but most of them are stupidly difficult. The game started to slog near the ending, getting QUITE repetitive. Thankfully it didn't go on any longer than necessary.

Definitely worth it on sale!

ASAMU is a competent and relaxing parkour platformer with a solid story and decent mechanics.

7/10

133722332.review:
I want to like A Story About My Uncle. The videos for it on Steam made it look great, but it is far from polished. In jumpers like this, I usually enjoy screaming, "not OSHA compliant!" as I miss a jump and fall to my doom. That takes a game that engages you. Sadly, this one does not. Half of what engages is the mechanics. Those are generally solid, if sometimes frustrating, as some surfaces for a grapple don't work in some instances where they do in other instances. In fact it was one of these that made me just give up on the game all together. A nice protruding rock with a glowing run that I simply could not grapple. The second have of what engages [me] is story. This story is pretty thin. I can almost forgive the world not making sense because you are narrating a supposedly exciting story, but when that narration takes place it is horribly delivered. Side characters, like Madie are fine; its the main character. Not only does he respond to other characters as though he's talking to his audience, creating dissonance, but he delivers his lines with the worse pauses and stops than a 70s martial arts dub.

That really is A Story About My Uncle: game mechanics that are almost there, but buggy, and a story that is almost there, but poorly told.

132812186.review:
Frustrating. That’s how I’d sum up this game. 

TLDR: I have completed the game at time of review, and I can confidently say everything is /almost/ good. Story is almost good and the narrator is the only real thing holding it together. Main reason I kept playing instead of quitting instantly at the hour mark. Gameplay and controls could almost be good. But it falls short (literally & metaphorically) and becomes an annoying, rage-inducing mess. 

The core gameplay is a grapple & power-jump mechanic. You’d expect it to follow a kind of ‘normal’ physics, similar to a spiderman swing, but NO. It does whatever it wants and isn’t very repeatable. This leads to an exasperating experience where you keep plowing directly into rocks just to loose your momentum, fall and die. Your jump dosen’t sync very well to the audio cue, and sloppy controls don’t sync well, so you jump short, fall and die. Other times you can’t see the destination and then fall and die. It’s not fun. It could have been, but it isn't. 

Everything else about the game is just…alright. Story is cute, but not compelling. Music is there. Characters are pretty one dimensional. The whole 'story' is to find your Uncle, and you do, but for less than two minutes, and he sends you back away to never see him again. There is a translatable language, but no reason to figure it out. The one enemy you encounter is just to annoy you rather than present an actual challenge.

A Story About My Uncle is a unique and creative first-person platformer that tells a heartwarming story about a boy's journey to find his missing uncle. The game's visuals are stunning, with beautiful landscapes and imaginative environments that immerse the player in the story. The controls are smooth and responsive, making it easy to navigate through the game's challenging platforming sections.

On the downside, the game's puzzles can be a bit frustrating at times. Some of the solutions are not immediately obvious, and players may find themselves stuck for a while trying to figure out what to do next. Additionally, the game's story can be a bit confusing at times, with some plot points not being fully explained.

Overall, A Story About My Uncle is a visually stunning and imaginative platformer that tells a heartwarming story. The game's challenging platforming and puzzles may be frustrating at times, but the beautiful visuals and immersive environments make up for it. If you're a fan of platformers and enjoy a good story, this game is definitely worth checking out.

I uh... genuinely am unsure how to rate this game, for now it is a positive review but it is so close to the edge that I honestly might flip it to negative on any day.
This game started amazing, I had such high hopes but the game just crushes them all so suddenly...

The game is a platformer, and a fun one at that, it features an gorgeously fascinating world I truly wanted to know more about but never got any answers to, I loved the characters I met and had a great time playing the game, only for it stop so suddenly dead in it's tracks that it still leaves me frustrated everytime I see this game pop up in my steam library years later. I truly loved what this game offered until it just.. rammed into a dead end.

The game features a mysterious fantasy world which keeps opening up more and more to the player during the game only for it to come to the most abrupt end I've ever seen in a game. I truly cannot describe this in any other way than stopping it's story completely where normally would be the middle point of any other.

Furthermore I am also an achievement-hunter to a small extent and one of the achievements is quite easy while all the others are absolutely brutal, this darn game has been a thorn in my completion % for years now.

The game is only lasted 2.5 hours for me until I reached the end, and I spent 30 minutes if not longer than that on a random goofy challenge I wanted to do. with a $10 price tag that is very questionable, at least this game is almost always for 80% or more on sale somewhere.

Truly the biggest dissapointment I've had in my gaming history but the parts it did have were truly enjoyable. I am genuinely unsure if I should keep this review as positive or make it negative.

129454951.review:
'A Story About My Uncle' is a Spider-Man web slinging game. No, there's no actual Spider-Man here, but the most prevalent gameplay mechanic here is shooting an energy rope at targets and using them to swing to further targets. You're only allowed to land on small floating islands; missing a target or an island usually means plummeting to your death and quickly being reset to the first part of the chain of islands you're trying to get through at the moment.

Reaching some places also requires high-jumps and sprinting off the edges of islands, and there are also a few more abilities I didn't reach yet; I gave up at almost three hours, probably halfway or 2/3 of the way through the game. The problem is that it's tedious; the targets are small and easy to miss unless you've flung yourself just right. Also, your energy rope pulls you straight towards them, and touching them stops your forward momentum and usually results in a death and a reset. (The reset never undoes much progress, but several places required dozens of attempts to get past, and that was frustrating.) It's also completely linear, meaning that the only exploration you'll do is to figure out where you're supposed to go next (which is more difficult than it should have been in the caves, which were very dark and made me with the settings had a gamma setting; once I set the brightness at the very beginning of the game I saw no way to change it).

The writing is a little bit clumsy, and the voice actors are stiff. There are collectibles to find, but the difficulty of making any progress through the levels stole any desire I had for that.

This game has promise, but I think it needs to have been made quite a bit more forgiving and also have some of the long repetitive sequences trimmed down. I'm a little curious about what happened to the uncle, but I don't seem to have either the skill or the patience to get there.

128541054.review:
this game is decent it just didnt satisfy my personal needs. 
pros: 
- beautiful world
- simple and casual gameplay 
- big replayability IF you liked it (time trials mostly: has great potential for speed running) 

cons:
- lots of visual bugs, inconsistencies (it is VERY easy to crawl into walls, under the ground and have objects half-block your view while in the air because you are half-inside them)
- game mechanics are inconsistent as well: sometimes u lose momentum, sometimes you dont. very frustrating to deal with at times. The basic idea is really cool but I feel like it could have been honed much more precisely
- the most frustrating part for me was, I didnt know where to go at some places: The surroundings are beautiful, dont get me wrong, but extremely repetitive so it is sometimes very hard to make out what you already have passed and what is your road to walk. That happened quite a lot because of the aforementioned visual issues.

I didnt take much joy from this but got mostly frustrated, even though I saw great potential in this game: I only finished it in order to get closure: the story is okay with a small second layer of plot revealing itself at the end (which disappointed me tbh). Voice acting was meh 
in conclusion: I would give it a 5/10 but tended towards thumbs down because I really didnt enjoy it much even though this is exactly my kinda game. 
little tip: "The valley" does basically the same as this game but much better in terms of physics and visuals. But at the expense of a story :)

Some of the worst "grapple" mechanics I've ever seen. 
You know what makes grappling fun? Momentum. 
You know what you lose the moment you un-grapple mid air? Momentum! 
My god, its like the moment you let go of the grapple button your character might as well just stop mid air. 
Maybe this grapple function would be worth it if the level design reflected that. But if in the first hour of gameplay I'm running into moments where I need to cheese just to get by, and I'm wondering "what do they want me to do here?" it's not worth playing.

The plot seemed kinda half baked from the start so I don't feel like I'm really missing out on much.

124729420.review:
Wow. This game is bad. It might be one of the worst I've ever played, it surely is the worst in its genre and by far the worst in my whole steam account.

A Story about my Uncle is a perfect demonstration of how not to make a platformer, or a game in general. The controls, the collisions, the overall feel, the precision - they all feel off. You will fall hundreds, thousands of times (which is okay concearning difficulty because checkpoints are very frequent) while most of the time thinking "why did he slide off, I was standing on solid ground?", "Why did he fall, I grabbed the rock?", "How could I miss that, the crosshair even lit up?", "Why didn't he jump, I released the button in time?!" and so on and so on. 

Compared to other platformers where you see your mistake and know how to correct it, this game has to be learned pretty hard because you have to get used to do it "wrong", to jump too early to press buttons at awkward timings etc. 
This is not the first game of this kind I've played: I have played and am a big fan of Mirror's Edge, I also enjoy both Dying Lights and, while I did not like the difficulty, Ghost Runner is also a game I've played for some time. So I know about first person platforming, have some experience and no, the game itself does not lag either. It really comes down to the game's design and neither my experience or hardware.

Yes, you can learn it. 
Yes, checkpoints are frequent and fair. 
So yes, you can complete it quite easily.

But no, if the whole game feels glitchy, unresponsive and therefore unfair, you have failed at crating a platformer. This is not about the difficulty, the game is frustrating for it's terrible movement.

To stay fair I've even sunk some mkore hours into the game, even trying to get the grapple and no-fail achievements. This is not a hasty rant, I've completed the game once and another time for achievements and collectibles. And I feel ashamed for having wasted all that time because even now after being really "good" at the game - compensating horrible controls and ridiculously bad design that is - I still hate it passionately and can't believe this game got shipped in this state.

Oh yes, and another minor thing: Don't expect a good story. Even as a Walking Simulator, even if you play "just for the story", you will be disappointed nontheless. The story is okay, kinda cute - but it leads to nothing, there is no twist, no interesting plot. The game looks nice and tries to show you a fantastic world, but everything is empty and quite boring, there is nothing to explore or experience.


Truly one of the worst games of it's kind. I played years ago and was hoping for updates to fix the broken controls and systems, but unfortunately after replaying it the last few days I could only see that this game remains broken and unfun. A through and through terrible experience. Avoid at all costs.

124355928.review:
This game is for 8-year-olds and speedrunners.
There's no inbetween.
Fair of a short story, nothing too crazy. It's about loving your family.
If you're in for a casual game-session and a bedtime story, buy it.
Otherwise it's just another platformer that falls short in content and doesn't really provide much challenge.
If you're clumsy like me, you'll fail a few landings before figuring out the timing.
That's the only thing that kept me for three hours in this game, which I do not regret.
As for the visuals, it's nice. Beyond outdated graphics (not that I care) art direction did a good job on making their world appealing to the eye.
Animations on NPC are a little clumsy, but it sorta gives the game a charm in the few interactions you have with them (there aren't many, though).

Pros:
Easy to learn
Has a time trial
Nice visuals
Good platforming
Wholesome story

Cons:
Too short
Repetitive gameplay
Clumsy animations

122996825.review:
ASAMU is a pretty decent game. The gameplay is phenomenal and endlessly fun and replayable. It's one of those games for people who like to move fast, like Titanfall or Ultrakill, but as a calming almost puzzle-platformer. The art is wonderful and its EXTREMELY well optimized, running at least 40 FPS on even low-low end computers.

But not all is decent. The story is kind of uninteresting, as are the characters. The voice acting is actually terrible as well, some of the worst game voice acting I've heard. Even Hunt Down the Freeman does better in this department. The only well-acted character is Fred. I can't decide if the narrator or Maddie are more poorly acted, but its a close, low bar. The narrator falls extremely flat, as does Maddie. 

I won't knock the va for Maddie much because I can't tell if its a child or not. As for the narrator, though, every line delivered fell entirely flat, and it did not sound human. I understand this is an indie title, and we can't always hire Matt Mercer, but thats a skill you really need to work on if you want to be in this field. I feel that even an average person could have delivered the lines better. 

It's overall a solid 7/10, hard carried by the immaculate gameplay and level design.

121745856.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

120813628.review:
As a bedtime story, a man tells his daughter about the time he went off to search for his uncle on one of his adventures. You play as the man's younger self, equipped with your inventor uncle's various contraptions to navigate the cavelike world he was last known to explore. The devices power up as you go along, to the point that by the end you can cross tremendous distances and soar over great chasms. 

The sensation is both tense and relaxing, like swimming in the air, or maybe a sci-fi twist of swinging on vines like Tarzan. The game feels like a very pleasant medley of other influences too: You've got the [i]Unreal[/i] engine world and physics, with puzzle mechanics and progression like [i]Portal[/i] (a theme with many of the games in my library), a [i]Myst[/i]-like soundtrack and ambience, in a world reminiscent of [i]Journey to the Center of the Earth[/i]. I think Steam recommended this one to me because of one or more of these influences, but I'm not sure.

I played this one because it's one of the shorter ones in my library, with an expected playtime of 3-9 hours. This playthrough took me about 5 hours. I had played once before several years ago, but didn't remember much about it, not even where I stopped. [spoiler](Think it was shortly after meeting Maddy.)[/spoiler] A friend got it because he saw me playing it and [i]he[/i] finished it, but I never got around to finishing it until now. Near the end, your character says of Fred "If he could do this, I can"; similarly, my friend's winning the game gave me the extra "It can be done!" kick I needed to finish this one up.

The puzzles are not usually hard to figure out, but can be tricky to execute. Having a moving keyboard drawer can make them even more difficult. I did get stuck in a few places, but getting unstuck typically just meant hovering the cursor over things until it lit up. I technically didn't complete one puzzle: The game gave me a hint, and then when I failed many times and came close one time, it eventually (kindly) let me progress without fully solving it myself. The achievements tend to be either finishing a level without dying (er, falling, no lives in this game [i]per se[/i]) or doing it under a certain number of moves. If you're a very careful player, you might be able to get these in your first try. ([i]Narrator[/i]: Daniel was [b]not[/b] a careful player.) I would play this game again to try to master the levels enough to get the achievements.

There are also collectibles, which look like seismographs (saying so because the first one I saw I took for a regular prop) and which you can hone in on from their beeping noises. I only unlocked one Unlockable, which was a mode to change my beam color from blue to any custom color of my choice. And I think it happened because I collected X number of collectibles. There's a counter of how many you've collected so far in your Esc menu options. (I didn't see a similar counter for how many grapples you've used, so you may need to count those yourself -- or use as few as you can -- for the achievements.)

Pretty solid game, although I got caught in the geometry a few times. When I got caught, it was usually trying to figure out how to start a puzzle, rather than being in the middle of executing one. This happened in the ice cave level especially, where the geometry is very creative. Fortunately the game has a checkpoint system at fairly frequent intervals, with an option in the Esc menu to restart from the last one passed.

It packs in a lot of story for not being a long game, and does a very good job I felt with the story's closure. It's a nice, quick, fun yet challenging game!

120740194.review:
First person platformers can be hit and miss but A Story About My Uncle was highly enjoyable for the most part. It had some annoying bits near the end but this was a minor nuisance. My issue near the end was that it became difficult to determine what chunks of ground and rock one could grapple to. I didn’t seem to have this issue before the ice caves level for whatever reason but it meant a lot more deaths than normal. The windmills earlier were also quite finicky. Overall I liked the grappling system as it made me try to plan out a route before taking the first jump. There are also a decent amount of augments you get such as extra grapples; rocket boots; super jumps; and cores that recharge your grapple mid flight. All of this makes you strategize when to use them so you don’t run out mid flight. The story was at times basic but had some promise. You are searching for your missing uncle and need to explore this strange world to find him. My only complaint was that you don’t learn more about the frog people and their history. For instance you get a companion who deciphers glyphs for you but they don’t stick around long and there are plenty of glyphs after that point that I would have liked to know what they meant. The voice acting was very good. There wasn’t much music in the game to judge. The graphics were decent overall. It was never a stunner but had some good art direction. The only bits that I thought looked weak, even for 2014, was the fire; hair and the frog people’s feet. There were also some awkward transitions in the game where it loaded the next section of the game but only had a blank black screen. These transitions only took a couple seconds on my SSD but the first couple made me think maybe the game had frozen. I think adding a “loading” message would have been better. The ending seemed to be a bit flat and weak but I suggest waiting for after the credits when there is a post credits scene which ties things up nicer. 

	I played A Story About My Uncle on Linux. It never crashed and I didn’t notice any bugs. The game saves at checkpoints. Usually I don’t like this over manual saves  but these were spaced out well for the most part and weren’t a big problem. The game has a v-sync toggle; an FOV slider that goes from 60-120; three graphics settings; and three AA settings. I left V-Sync off as the game picked up my 144Hz refresh rate without it. Alt-Tab worked. The performance was very good. There were a couple bits where the frame rate dropped to 58 and 59 but these accounted for a total of about two minutes of my overall play time which was next to nothing. Typically the frame rate was above 80 FPS and was even over 100 FPS for a large chunk as well. I found that a keyboard and mouse worked great for this game which was impressive as platformers can be a mixed bag with them.

Game Engine: Unreal 3
Graphics API: OpenGL
Game Version Played: Build 5188
Disk Space Used: 1.3 GB
Input Used: Keyboard and mouse

Graphics Settings Used:  V-Sync off; FOV 100; all high; motion blur off; 8x AA
GPU Usage: 0-100 %
VRAM Usage: 737-915 MB
CPU Usage: 8-25 %
RAM Usage: 2.2-3.5 GB
Frame Rate: 58-144 FPS

	Overall I think A Story About My Uncle was a solid platformer. If you like games like Valley you should like this. The story and presentation were good and the game play was more fun then nuisance. It had some areas to improve but was still enjoyable. I finished this play through in three hours and six minutes. I think it is worth it’s current price tag of $16.79 CAD. 

My Score: 7.5/10

Sin embargo:

1.-El control de la cámara con el látigo es pésimo. Una cosa es difícil, y otra frustrante. Se han condensado todas las habilidades en 3 teclas, lo que hace que no actúe de la forma deseada muchas veces.

2.- La jugabilidad, bastante mala. El diseño de los mapas, a mi parecer, es nefasto. En vez de balancearte con el látigo, te aproximas a las rocas, y según le de al juego, te balanceas o te estampas.

3.- ¿Sirve de algo averiguar los mensajes ocultos?-no, hasta dónde yo he visto. No se puede interactuar con la gente, salvo que sea parte de la historia lineal.

4.-Aunque parece que te explican porqué flotan los islotes...no hay nada que se relaciona con la justificación que se da.

7.- La historia..sin más, podría haber estado mejor, pero es 'digerible'.

¿Qué tiene de bueno?- A mi parecer, el doblaje

En vez de haberse dedicado a dejar todo al milímetro para frustar al jugador, deberían haberse enfocado en enriquecer el mapa y la historia, dando paso a la rejugabilidad cuando descubrieses parte de la historia y, a raíz de eso, poder enfocar otras partes de la historia de diferente modo, para así conseguir algún otro final, atajos o alguna mejora que hiciese más entretenida la experiencia.

En estos juegos que se centrar en una historia, la jugabilidad tendría que ser fluida y agradable para poder ir avanzando sin perder el hilo de la trama; lo contrario de lo que ocurre en este juego. Ya que con la frustración, el juego no es disfrutable, te encallas y puedes perder los detalles de la trama (ya que el objeto de la trama se indica nada más empezar y no varía).

119313083.review:
A fantastic casual exploration game! 

A Story About My Uncle starts when your daughter asks for a bedtime story. And what better story than you yourself - as a  young boy - discovering a ''portal' to another world, where you track your uncle Fred's footsteps, in hopes of finding him.

Using various mechanic (such as grapple hook, power jump and rocket boots) powered by your uncle's ingenious costume, you are on a lifetime adventure, throughout a mysterious world, discovering only bits of clues of what this mysterious place is, and where your uncle might be.

Don't be fooled - this game is awesome, with intriguing story and really fun mechanics. However, this is very casual adventure platformer - not a story rich game.

117325850.review:
Amid all the hubbub about video games being art, or being the next great popular medium, or whatever; it's easy to forget that video games are actually very fun for children, and thus are (were) primarily designed for children. A Story About My Uncle falls perfectly in this zone, and is an excellent kids' game. If you're looking to buy this for a pre-teen, like a 7 to 10-year-old, definitely go for it: the magic of a different world and strange aliens is well-realized, the story is simple enough, the graphics won't be a problem, and the levels are just difficult enough for their age range.

Unfortunately, about 95% of the people reading this review are grown-ass adults trying to discern whether they should themselves play this kids' game, because apparently you can't outgrow childish things anymore (see also: the Star Wars fandom). So for your sake, I'm gonna give this game a negative recommendation, though it realistically doesn't deserve it.

116833843.review:
--- GAMEPLAY ---
The platforming and movement in this game is excellent. Moving around the set paths feels very smooth when you get a good rhythm going. There is never really any major combat or enemies in the game besides for one major one so there was never really much of a challenge besides for a few more difficult areas to traverse and a few times where the environment was changed so I had to take a few times to attempt to get through one area.

--- STORY ---
The world building is good, from the start when you are first learning about your uncle while following in his path to find him to learning about the strays and their break off society. I was really engrossed in it as I played. The main narrator is great with most of the other voice acting being mostly good. Some of the bugs in the game did kind of make me do a reality check though as the npcs could be a bit janky

--- Worth The Price ---
At the time of review the price is: £11.39
Worth the price? No, not at full price. The game only took me less than 3 hours to complete. On a heavy sale it is worth it.

I know that it looks like I haven't played this much, but that's not true. I've played and gotten 100% of everything in this game on a friend's account when I couldn't afford this game, and though I am ashamed to admit it, I pirated this game on a crappy old laptop that could barely run it. That all said, this is my favourite game of all time. I know it has bugs, I know it has a lot of low quality things in it. But something about this game makes me love it even more than any triple A game I've played, or any other indie game with a lot of heart and soul in it. I love this game, and now that I finally own it, I will never remove it from my computer. I love this game so much, and recommend it to anyone who thinks it looks even slightly interesting. 

TL;DR, I love this game, and you should buy it.

115920710.review:
Finished the game in 3 hours. There are some hidden items that you can try to collect. Flying and jumping was fun. After a while, you get to do new stuff to keep you from getting bored with doing the same thing. The goal of the game is to go from point A to point B, and there are many different paths that you can take. There is no time pressure, so pretty chill. Nothing outrageously difficult. The controls can be better, but it is more than sufficient to complete the game.

Story is meh. Voice acting is meh. I want to say the game is too short, but honestly, I would quit anyways if the game is longer, so I am glad it is over, which is a terrible thing to say about a game. There are moments that the game try really hard to be sentimental, but they are really not emotional at all. 

Definitely not worth it at full price. Maybe $5 at most.

113650474.review:
[i]A Story About My Uncle[/i] is a first-person platformer with narrative elements. While a pretty game to look at with some rare moments of heart, this game struggles to satisfy as a platformer or a walking simulator. Lacking an emotional core to motivate player investment or a stable platforming system that doesn't result in constant false starts, this game can only be recommended as a curiosity to those interested in how an action-driven walking sim would play. Otherwise, stick to games that excel at either of those genres individually.

You play as a nameless nephew, reliving the story of his wondrous adventure in search of his uncle Fred. In searching for Fred, you must follow in the man's footsteps - across vast swaths of open air, chasms littered with floating rocks that are only navigable thanks to Fred's inventions. Largely through the use of a grappling beam, make your way through a half-dozen terrains as you meet different peoples, discover ancient remnants, and try to piece together what happened to uncle Fred.

[i]A Story About My Uncle[/i] tries to merge two typically separate genres: platformers and walking simulators. This game's gameplay largely consists of platforming, while it borrows the exploratory/narrative elements, short length, and the general structure of walking sims. Unfortunately, this game delivers underwhelming experiences on both fronts and thus leaves fans of either genre feeling disappointed. On the walking sim side, the game's story is bare-bones and lacking in emotional depth. Too many opportunities to offer immersion or character to the world are neglected, and what is shown feels one dimensional. Uncle Fred is too distant and enigmatic a character to develop strong feelings over, and there are simply no other characters worth mentioning - not even the one other named character. The epilogue is about the only time the game gets close to pulling a heartstring, though even the execution of that leaves players with more questions than answers.

In terms of the platforming, [i]A Story About My Uncle[/i] delivers choppy and unpredictable gameplay. Grappling across sheer expanses should offer a thrilling breath of fresh air to players, but the experience more often verges on a strain as players must contend with the game's minimal UI and midair aiming akin to drunk Tarzan swinging on vines. The first major fault is the lack of notice for whether a player would be in range to grapple with an object in the distance; depth perception is shoddy in this game, leading to a ton of false start deaths. Momentum control is another, as plenty of barely-visible/moving areas prevent the player from accurately gauging whether they will hit the surface they're grappling towards, causing mid-flight death. Midair aiming can also be needlessly complicated by the lack of full 360-degree aiming, forcing players to sometimes lose bearings in low-light zones and thus get stuck trying to maneuver to latch onto a ceiling target while falling. The memorable pitfalls of this game's platforming outweigh its moments of wonder and exuberant traversal, that's for sure.

The game has relatively few strengths to compensate for its weaknesses. The environment design is one highlight: glowing blues and warm oranges color a luscious world, which though repetitive can help please the eyes over the course of the playtime. The soundtrack is not very memorable, though it too pads over areas with sufficient replayability. There are some bits of narrative dialogue offered via mementos scattered about the world that occasionally convey some charm. In terms of replay value, secrets scattered about the levels tied to unlocking new gameplay features could incentivize players who can tolerate the platforming to return.

[i]A Story About My Uncle[/i] is a cautionary tale about the experimental mixing of game genres. This game at its core seems to want to deliver the walking sim experience of an emotional journey about family and loss, but decided to dedicate most time and energy to implementing first-person platformer gameplay, largely botched that, and left the narrative elements underdeveloped as a result. Ultimately, while this game could still be appealing to genre die-hards and might even be worth a tepid recommendation at a sale price, there are simply better platformers and walking sims to spend your time with. [i]A Story About My Uncle[/i] gets a C.

112954236.review:
More of a "meh" than a thumbs down. Very low playtime (~2-3 hours) for the full price (but worth it for $1 from Humble Bundle like I got).

Feels more like a tech demo.

Voice acting is amateur, story is ho-hum and gets in the way. Also has a really off color part where the character is asked if they romantically liked a teenage frog creature, um...okay weird.

The core mechanics are interesting and I wish they had been explored more instead: traversing terrain with a jump, 3 charges of a grapple hook, and rocket boots. Instead the levels are linear, and most require a certain order to be able to get to the next platform/location. And they all have a hint of what to grapple so there is very minimal exploration or deviation from the "approved" path. Nice scenery in a couple levels, others are forgettable caves, and there's really only 5 maps total.

Basically I'd like this game more if I was a merchant/explorer/pirate/something traversing and doing things in an expanded, somewhat open world version of the Star Haven map. Alternatively I'll just play the Scout in Deep Rock Galactic, where most of my grappling hook skills came from haha.

112125891.review:
2.5 hours for $14...
Okay well, lets begin with something. A Story about My Uncle is a story where you hunt down your uncle through some strange fantasy sky-realm populated by frog-people. You do meet some frog-girl but damn if I cant remember her name, in fact all of the characters you meet, I cant remember. They seem to be really cookie-cutter and really poorly acted. The animations are really dodgy at best, as it seems like around the second act of the story, the characters started lacking a lot of detail in their animations, only using key frames.
I finished this game in two hours, and apparently it can be finished even faster than that. Thing is, I was kinda hoping there was more and was sorely disappointed that there wasn't. 
Onto Character Arcs... There are none. The for girl decides to tag along with you for a noble reason "finding your uncle" but then in the next chapter decides to stay behind in the skylands because she didn't really want to find your uncle, she just wanted to escape. The story is written to think that this is a big decision, but the fact is that an hour of knowing her is not enough for me to get invested in her, and as such I really didn't care if she stayed or left. At least there's a time-trial mode, if you're into that.
I also found that sometimes the platforming didn't work quite as it should. There were several times where I'd click on the crystals several times, and I'd never shoot them with my gauntlet beam which caused me to fall.
4/10: A good game if you're just looking for platforming that seldom works, but please for all that is holy do not buy this for the full price.

111307204.review:
There is charm and there is whimsy. There is wholesomeness and there is genuine emotion. However, those things cannot make up for the rough parts the hold this video game back. This video game claims you can grapple from almost anywhere and that is simply not true. Specially towards the end of the video game the places in which you can grapple are few and far between. I understand this is intended but then it shouldn't be stated that the player can grapple almost anywhere. Not to mention the darker portions make it near impossible to see where you're going while trying to figure out "on the fly" where you can grapple, let alone see the points you CAN grapple from.
The controls while simple have nuances that are not explained which leads to frustrating bouts of trial and error. There is pleasant music throughout which keeps the player calm during the frustrating portions.
The characters and backgrounds are rough. It is obvious this was done independently however some things are just poorly done. The voice acting while well done, is brought low by poor animations and jagged edges. Denny Crane.

110803537.review:
A simple request for a bedtime story from your daughter has you remembering Uncle Fred; a man who has long since vanished on a spontaneous adventure with no one knowing exactly where he wandered off to – except for you. Retell a magical adventure full of mysteries and intrigue, of strange creatures, enchanting caverns, dangerous beasts, and otherworldly places; the story about your uncle.  


[b]Warning: this game can give you motion sickness; this issue is resolved by going into options and removing motion blurring and/or speed lines.[/b]

Before you buy, I’m going to note here that I only recommend it depending on why you want to play A Story About My Uncle. If you want to play for the story, or you like speed runs and optional timed challenges, then yes, you’ll probably like this! If you’re playing with the intention of getting 100%, I doubt you will. A handful of achievements are actually kind of difficult to get, beating the game will take about 3+ hours, but 100%’ing it? 10+. One is getting a gold medal on all timed challenges and the time constraints are… not going to be giving you much room for mistakes.
With that out of the way, the story is pretty good, the gameplay itself is really fun, you fly around 5 areas with a grappling hook and the speeds you can hit are exhilarating. Some of the paths you need to take aren’t obvious and there is a bit of room for exploration, but all stages are linear. There are a bunch of collectables and story objects to interact with to enhance the world building, but the game ending is a bit disappointing. While I don’t fully recommend A Story About My Uncle, I definitely don’t hate it enough to give a negative review.  

TL;DR: 3-10+ hrs, good story, fun gameplay, exhilarating speeds. Optional timed speedrun challenges and plenty of story collectables. Hard to 100%; ending falls a bit flat, play it if you want.

110605292.review:
If you plan on playing this game be mentally prepared for a tough, intense and unforgiving platformer.

[u]PROS[/u]
 - This game was developed by a tiny team and they've managed to create an impressive and unique first-person platformer
- The platforming is challenging and creative
- The story is simple but touching

[u]CONS[/u]
- The platforming (which consists of 100% of the game as there is no combat) starts off easy but ramps up with each chapter, culminating in a difficult to very difficult (depending on player skill) final stage in the ice caverns that might have many players throwing in the towel out of sheer frustration & anger. I managed to complete the game but by the 2nd-to-last and final chapter I was cursing out the developers, raging and considered quitting once or twice.

-Now I'm no stranger to tough platformers; I've played and completed Ghost Runner which is touted as one of the hardest platformer games ever but the difficulty there felt fair. However, in this game the lock-on system for the grapple felt way too specific/finicky and there were many, many times when I felt like I should have been able to grapple onto a floating rock/etc only to plummet to my death, yet again.

110575946.review:
Fun core gameplay of jumping, grappling, boosting and zooming along islands in the sky; probably springing from someone asking "is a supercharged grappling hook enough to base a game on?" and based a game on it.

Earlygame with expanding toolkit, and midgame with expanded challenges keep a great sense of flow and difficulty making leaping through the sky a smooth and entertaining experience as you quickly get into the rythm of slingshotting yourself at high speeds through the rocky platforms making up the course.
Sadly, the last level of the game is fairly tedious, with an early unfun surprise challenge, and later some "unmarked" unusable platforming while the previous "leaps of fate" stops really conveying where to go, hampering the flow which made the early game great.

Cozy characters, well one, made the journey enjoyable even if it halts completely in the final chapter.

Recommended for a fun novel platforming experience.

109519310.review:
It's meh.
I think I got it for free a while back. I wouldn't pay for it.
It's pretty short, which means the story doesn't really take off. Voice acting is bad. Level design is bad - either too easy with save points every step of the way or suddenly none for a whole section. Puzzles are more in the direction of "guess what you have to click on now to continue. Could it be this big thing right in the middle of the room?"
I really don't like the mechanics. At all. You fling yourself around in order to reach the next platform. God forbid you touch anything or you're dead. Also there's three different kinds of jumping - normal (space), high (right mouse), and far (right mouse + sprint). Why? No idea - you stop using normal jump straight away. Why do you need to charge the other two? Also no idea. There's no reason.
Then I struggled with depth perception a lot. Can I reach this island with a far jump? Oh shit, jumped all the way over it. Can I reach this other one with a high jump? Ah nope, wayyy farther than I though.

The ambiance is really nice, though.

All in all you're being dropped into a strange world that you get no explanation about where gravity seems to selectively only affect you, you jump around a bit, find the uncle you were looking for, say hi, and leave. No consequence. Might as well not have.
Oh, and also, you're apparently the only character without a name??

108735958.review:
Consider this a niche recommendation for a sale more than anything strong. It's far from a must-play experience, but ultimately I found that I enjoyed it.

"A Story About My Uncle" is a first person platforming game with a focus on a "grappling hook". It's a slow moving game that makes it relatively easy to get from point A to B. Even the hook isn't about smooth swinging and acrobatics... but functions as a hook shot that brings you straight forward. It works, but it feels more about being easy to handle rather than satisfying acrobatics. 

It's obviously intended as a chill experience with very little in the way of punishment, speed, precision or dangers. I jumped from A to B and talked to people about stuff. But this relaxation is both a blessing and a curse and it leaves me a bit confused on how I feel.

The thing is.. the last level wasn't chill. There was dangerous levels of butt clench as I was forced to string together jet boots, falling stalactites, ice walls and precise landings. I hated it for the stress levels, but it was also the first time that I was having fun. 

More fun events, unique challenges, and satisfying platforming occur in the last 25% of the game than in everything so far. It wasn't that they built up to it... but that they introduced the mechanics far too late and end up shoving half a games worth of progression into one awesome stage. 

But even at it's best, the level design had MAJOR problems guiding the player forward. Probably more than a dozen times in 3 hours of play I needed to stop and struggle to find where to go next. The levels are 3 dimensional with lots of vertical space, and are made up of random asteroids and floating islands that lack defining features. Half a dozen times I ended up making what looked like the only possible jump... only to realize that I'd returned to the start of a stage. 

The terrible guidance wasn't unforgivable because there's little punishment for mistakes, but it was a constant annoyance that started in the first stage and only ended with the game itself. Had there been an objective market, I'd probably have finished the game in an hour and half, but it would have been a better paced.

The game definitely ended on a high note and it's probably why I'm thumbs upping this. This could have been an absolutely amazing game had they unlocked skills earlier and introduced the challenges gradually... but as is.... its just a decent way to spend a few hours.

104584203.review:
[h1] Preface [/h1]
A Story About My Uncle is a First Person Platforming Game developed by Gone North Games and published by Coffee Stain Publishing. This genre is quite prone to being a mixed bag, and unfortunately this title is no different. Before I elaborate, allow me to post some bullet points:

[h2] PRO: [/h2]
+ Nice Visuals and Environments (if a little samey)
+ Nice Dialogue
+ Cool Premise
+ An Intriguing Mystery
+ Fun Side-lore

[h2] CON: [/h2]
- Very Rigid Controls, sometimes finnicky (no midair control)
- Optional collectables aren't fun to get, there is little sense of wonderment
- Empty feeling world (zero character interaction, most environments are dark, dreary, NPC placement feels very "sanitized", as if a bunch of Garry's Mod ragdolls having been frozen next to one another at semi-regular intervals)
- Not enough substance to warrant me continuing

[h2] Review: [/h2]
As an artist myself, I'm by no means here to bash the developers and be all angry and hateful. I enjoy the effort, and I definitely see a potential player base that could enjoy this game (even just judging by the amount of Steam Reviews).

The game is rather nice visually, some it's lore is interesting, the central mystery of the uncle's whereabouts is intruiging, but it all sort of lost steam for me by the 90 minute mark and I only played an additional twenty to see if it got any better. I'm sad to say: it did not.

Like mentioned in the overly long bullet points above: The game's world feels empty, the platforming just a little too slow, simple and yet strangely precise, a precision sadly not accounted for in the controls. For example there is this move the game shows you at the very start called the "power leap" where you perform a high jump ("super jump") and sprint at the same time, unfortunately, once you do so, you cannot adjust direction midair anymore.
The normal jump and power jump doesn't give you nearly as much forward momentum as you would expect either and the margin for error in actually jumping is little to none. In most platformer games, especially 2D ones, the game is automatically programmed so that there is a slight delay to when you're actually registered as having gone off a platform, so that if you press jump just a tiny bit too late, you still perform the jump (to account for the average human's reaction time and intuition). This is not present here and it feels wrong to me.

There is a village at the start of the game and it feels empty, there are obviously characters there, but they don't react to the player, barely to themselves even, as if they're all stuck in some far off fantasy land, perhaps a more engaging one than the one you, the player, are exploring. Them talking to each other makes barely any audible sound (if any! I actually can't remember.) And it all feels so "scripted" and, as said in the bullet points, "sanitary" like the NPCs have been surgically put there, with vast swaths of empty land and then a few NPCs and stock houses, placed at just the right angles, both the houses and the NPCs, it feels uncanny, as if lifeless life, a dollhouse hitting to close to actual home.

Lastly, and most importantly this was just not the game I was looking for. I recently played a game called "Cyber Hook", a fast paced first person platformer with a hookshot mechanic like the one here, but that one felt more organic, there was lots more momentum, speed and challenge that didn't feel stiff, meaning I could tackle a level in many ways. This game's grappling hook is just a puzzle mechanic, to a very simple puzzle, that feels unengaging to me, namely "get from point A, to point B".

It feels like the game is trying to have the precision and slow pace of a puzzle game, whilst simultaneously having the frankly banal gameplay loop of a normal platformer. Unfortunately there is a reason to why Sonic runs fast and Mario levels are filled to the brim with enemies, alt paths, pipes and powerups.

[h3]Much love to Gone North Games and Coffee Stain Publishing either way, I wish you luck with future projects. Who knows? Maybe I'll check your next game out and find it riveting. [/h3]

101020778.review:
Transported to a strange and wondrous world, one that you could never have imagined existed, you begin a long and perilous journey.  With your uncle’s inventions you explore this world, uncover clues as to the whereabouts of your missing uncle, and meet new friends along the way.

A Story About My Uncle is a first-person, narrative-driven platforming game where you travel through distinct areas in a strange world with the aid of several devices, most notable being a futuristic grappling hook.  Here you travel through the skies, up cliffs, and over yawning chasms by jumping, grappling, and swinging your way forward.  A Story About My Uncle is all about finding out where to go and figuring out how to get there.

While the game is interesting, it is far from fun.  There were issues with the grapple mechanic that slowed the game to a crawl.  The story, while interesting in the beginning, fell flat early on and ended poorly.  Additionally, the voice acting was poorly done and grating.  In the end, it came down to not only the mechanics for the grapple but the numerous inconsistencies of the distance in which to grapple an object.  In a game where the placement of the grapple is just as important as being able to grapple an object; it is important to make this aspect of the game work, and its failure made the game unpleasant and frustrating.  I would not play this game again.

All the achievements are challenge mode…for example, completing a level in a certain amount of time, or without falling, or using a limited number of grapples.  Getting these achievements will require multiple playthroughs and plenty of time and patience—but well worth it in the end.  The good thing is after completing the game the first time you can jump between chapters.  Additionally, you can get achievements by finding all the collectibles or optional story items.

I did not like A Story About My Uncle, but it was okay enough for me to finish the game.  While the game is pretty; the story is uninteresting, and the main mechanic is flawed.  There are far too many minor problems that I had with A Story About My Uncle to be able to recommend it.  If you like platforming games or challenging achievements then this may be the game for you, but I would have to say give A Story About My Uncle a hard pass.

[h1] Una aventura que comienza con un cuento para dormir [/h1]

[h1]Historia: [/h1]
Comenzamos desde la casa de nuestro tío Fred el cual ha estado desaparecido por bastante tiempo, indagando un poco más su hogar nos percatamos que en uno de los armarios hay un pequeño traje a la medida hecho para nosotros, al probarlo y seguir investigando damos con lo que parece ser un portal hacia otro mundo al que somos enviados y desde ahi comenzamos la travesia de hallar a nuestro tío Fred.

[h1] Jugabilidad: [/h1] 
El traje nos proporciona una especie de látigo con el cual el jugador puede engancharse a superficies flotantes o estáticas pero con un limite de usos antes de recargarse por lo cual se debe ser cuidadoso y pensar bien antes de moverse entre el escenario el cual por momentos se siente frustrante debido a que hay cierta dificultad con moverse entre las superficies y mientras más avanzamos entre los niveles se recibiran más habilidades al traje con lo cual se debe combinar para no caer al vacío, ciertamente suena dificil pero el juego nos lo facilita con los suficientes checkpoints para seguir adelante.

[h1] Banda sonora: [/h1]
Sin mucho que decir en este aspecto no es malo pero no sobresale de ninguna forma, da la sensación de que los desarrolladores se dejaron esto para el último.

En fin, no es un juego 10/10 ni una obra maestra pero sin duda es algo con lo que pasaras un buen rato :)

The use of the first-person narration is quite nice, and I feel it just enhances each section you play through. The game is telling a story, so why not have the character tell it too?
The visuals are great, with each section having it's own vibrant colour scheme that makes the environment really come alive while you play.
And my god, the gameplay. It's so fluid when you get the hang of it, and it doesn't feel repetitive with the progressive upgrades you're given. It mixes walking and exploring, jumping and swinging and hurtling through the air like a bullet really very nicely. 
I was loving playing through, and while short- maybe a few hours- it feels nicely paced, and there's definite replay value. 
The difficulty comes from the player's ability to work out where to go and to learn how the mechanics work, and while cartoonish, feels very meaningful. 
I love this game. Definitely play it.
